experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. Honestly, I’m just feeling a bit overwhelmed with everything and I’m not even sure where to start.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey, totally get it—I’ve been there too. Start small: pick one thing bugging you most, like grad school prep. Break it into steps—research programs, talk to professors for mentorship. You’re outgoing, so use that to network! For public speaking, practice in low-pressure settings first. You’ve got this—just take it one step at a time.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess I could try talking to Professor Evans after class. It's just that even thinking about grad school applications makes my stomach hurt.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a normal reaction—grad apps stress everyone out! But breaking it into tiny tasks helps. Start by just listing programs you're curious about—no pressure to commit yet. Professor Evans will appreciate your initiative. You're not alone in this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try making that list, but what if I pick the wrong programs? Professor Evans probably has way better students asking for recommendations anyway.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Don't overthink it—this list is just exploration, not a final decision! And professors expect students to ask; it's literally their job to mentor. Your curiosity and openness are huge strengths here. Start with 3-5 programs that genuinely interest you—no wrong answers at this stage.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could just email a few professors... but what if they think my questions are stupid?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Professors get emails like this all the time—they won’t think it’s stupid! Keep it simple: mention you’re exploring grad programs and ask if they’d be open to a quick chat. Your openness and curiosity are strengths here. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try, but what if they think my research interests aren't good enough? I just don't want to mess this up.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey, it's totally normal to feel that way! But remember—your interests are valid, and professors appreciate genuine curiosity more than "perfect" topics. You're not messing up; you're taking a brave step forward. Just be yourself and ask. You belong in those conversations!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but it just feels like everyone else already has their research figured out and I'm still just guessing. I'll try to say something in the next group meeting, though.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That "everyone else has it figured out" feeling is so common, but it's rarely true. Just asking one question in the meeting is a huge win—it shows you're engaged. You're not guessing, you're exploring, and that's exactly what you should be doing right now. Proud of you for stepping up

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess, but it still feels like I'm falling behind everyone in my algorithms class. Maybe I'll try asking one question in study group this week.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great plan! Study groups are perfect for this—everyone is there to learn, and someone else is probably wondering the same thing. Asking just one question can build momentum. You're not falling behind; you're actively catching up. Keep going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess you're right. It's just hard to feel like I'm catching up when everyone else seems to get it so easily.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It only *seems* that way because people don't show their struggle. I promise, you're not the only one working hard to grasp the material. Focus on your own progress—every question you ask is a step forward. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess... it's just hard to believe when everyone else looks like they have it all figured out in lecture. I'll try to ask more questions in study group.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly. Lecture halls can be intimidating, but study groups are your safe space to figure things out. Every expert was once a beginner who asked "dumb" questions. You're on the right track—keep leaning on your peers.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess you're right. It's just hard to remember that when I'm the one asking the question and feeling like I'm slowing everyone down.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Remember, a good study group helps everyone. Your question might be what someone else was too nervous to ask. You're contributing by creating an open space for learning. That's a strength, not a weakness.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe my awkward questions are actually helpful to anyone else.
